item.title: Max Stat 120 Errors
item.dc:creator: @Rodgerwilco Rodgerwilco
item.description:
@Rodgerwilco wrote:

Glad you learned something. Maybe you can just make the width of the stat window a few pixels wider to fit everything?

Just keep trying by trail and error and eventually you will get what you like or close to it.

Read full topic

item.title: Max Stat 120 Errors
item.dc:creator: @dds_ledg dds ledg
item.description:
@dds_ledg wrote:

[quote=“Rodgerwilco, post:7, topic:419467”][quote author=dds ledg link=topic=522012.msg3794874#msg3794874 date=1319561784]

public void drawString(String string, int x, int y, int k, int colour) {

}

Haven’t touched the client in quite some time but int k might be size.

I found that in GameImage.java, but what would I edit and change etc? Thanks for the help so far by the way, I really appreciate it
[/quote]

When “coding” you call upon a method. In this case the “drawString” method. The drawString method has 5 arguments. (String string, int x, int y, int k, int colour)

the string = 1
the x value = 2
the y value = 3
the (I am guessing size) = 4
color = 5

The gameGraphics is the class (.java file) which holds the .drawString method.

If I were to write up something from scratch it would be

^ most likely incorrect as I am going off the top of my head but you get the point.

hey = the string
1 = the x value
2 = the y value
5 = size
color = color (depending on how the method works)

This would be your concern.

Each argument is separated by a comma ,

skillArray[l1] + “:@yel@” + playerStatCurrent[l1] + “/” + playerStatBase[l1] = String
i + 5 = x value
i1 = y value
1 = size
i2 = color

That is… if int k is the size. If not hope you learned.[/quote]

Wow, thanks for the lesson. When I change the 1 at the end to a 2, it just makes it thinner, Like so in the pic below

The i + 5 moves it to the left for lower and right for higher, I experimented loads and came out with this: (Im so happy!)

I edited the i + 5 in the first row to i + 1 then did the same in the second row so it looked like this:

                gameGraphics.drawString(skillArray[l1] + ":@yel@" + playerStatCurrent[l1] + "/" + playerStatBase[l1], i + 1, i1, 1, i2);
                i2 = 0xffffff;
                if (super.mouseX >= i + 90 && super.mouseY >= i1 - 11 && super.mouseY < i1 + 2 && super.mouseX < i + 196) {
                    i2 = 0xff0000;
                    k1 = l1 + 9;
                }
                gameGraphics.drawString(skillArray[l1 + 9] + ":@yel@" + playerStatCurrent[l1 + 9] + "/" + playerStatBase[l1 + 9], (i + c / 2) - 1, i1, 1, i2);
                i1 += 13;
            }

This moves the stats along to the right and left slightly =D this took about 20 mins of testing btw lol

Read full topic

When “coding” you call upon a method. In this case the “drawString” method. The drawString method has 5 arguments. (String string, int x, int y, int k, int colour)

the string = 1
the x value = 2
the y value = 3
the (I am guessing size) = 4
color = 5

The gameGraphics is the class (.java file) which holds the .drawString method.

If I were to write up something from scratch it would be

hey = the string
1 = the x value
2 = the y value
5 = size
color = color (depending on how the method works)

This would be your concern.

Each argument is separated by a comma ,

skillArray[l1] + “:@yel@” + playerStatCurrent[l1] + “/” + playerStatBase[l1] = String

1 = size
